qas.question: What concepts are fundamental to number theory?

answers.text: adele rings and adelic algebraic groups

qas.question: What group uses infinite field extensions with topology?
What is used to generalize the connection of fields and groups to infinite field extensions?
What group is an advanced observation of infinite field extensions and groups that is adapted for the needs of algebraic geometry?
What is basic to adele rings?
Which Galois group does not use topology?
What form of topology do Matrix groups use?
The Galois group is adapted to the needs of what form of geometry?
What is algebraic geometry adapted to the needs of?

context: for any constant c. Matrix groups over these fields fall under this regime, as do <a0_0>adele rings and adelic algebraic groups<a0_0/>, which are basic to <b4_0>number theory<b4_0/>. Galois groups of infinite field extensions such as <a1_0>the <b5_0>absolute<b5_0/> Galois group<a1_0/> can also be equipped with a topology, the so-called <a2_0><b6_0>Krull<b6_0/> topology<a2_0/>, which in turn is central to generalize the above sketched connection of fields and groups to infinite field extensions. An advanced generalization of this idea, adapted to the needs of <b7_0>algebraic<b7_0/> geometry, is <a3_0><b8_0>the étale fundamental group<b8_0/><a3_0/>.
